Class LinearFilter

  • java.lang.Object
    • synthExperiments.Signal
      • synthExperiments.LinearFilter

extends Signal

      • getFreqResponse

        public Signal getFreqResponse()
        A deep copy of the table with frequency response of the filter. No references, so no hacking here ;)
        Returns:
        A clone of the signal with frequency response of this filter

      • setGain

        public void setGain(double gain)
        Sets gain. Requires recalculating all the filter (which is a quadratic operation).

      • setCutoff

        public void setCutoff(double cutoff)
        Sets cutoff frequency. Requires recalculating all the filter (which is a quadratic operation).

      • setFilterLength

        public void setFilterLength(int N)
        Sets filter length. Requires recalculating all the filter (which is a quadratic operation).

      • setSampleRate

        public void setSampleRate(int s)
        Sets sample rate. Requires recalculating all the filter (which is a quadratic operation).
        Overrides:
        setSampleRate in class Signal

      • filter

        public Signal filter(Signal s)
              throws java.lang.Exception
        Gets a signal as parameter and returns the filtered signal
        Parameters:
        s - The signal which will be filtered
        Returns:
        The signal s after being filtered
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • calcFrequencyResponse

        protected void calcFrequencyResponse()
                              throws java.lang.Exception
        Builds filter's frequency response based on parameters stored
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • isFrequencyInRange

        protected abstract boolean isFrequencyInRange(double freq)
        Code here must answer to the question: when is a certain frequency set to ZERO or set to GAIN? For example, for a high pass filter: freq >= cutoff (&& freq <= sampleRate-cutoff).
        Parameters:
        freq - The frequency we want to check.
        Returns:
        TRUE or FALSE, whether this frequency is in filter range or not.

      • calcImpulseResponse

        protected void calcImpulseResponse()
        Calculates impulse response based on frequency response

      • shiftHalves

        public void shiftHalves()
        Permutates the halves of impulse response table. This is equivalent to Scilab's FFTSHIFT. Examples: [1 2 3 4 5 6] -> shiftHalves() -> [4 5 6 1 2 3] [1 2 3 4 5] -> shiftHalves() -> [3 4 5 1 2]

      • calculateFilter

        protected void calculateFilter()
        Recalculate filter
